AGaynst the quartayne of a burnt choler in somer, take of Endiue, cychory, Hartes tounge, citterache, maydeÃÑ here, teint wort, ana. m i. of violettes .‚Ñ• iiii. of borage floue ‚Ä¢ s .‚Ñ• ii. of the .iiii. colde seades melons Gourdes, cucumers Pepons, ana. ‚Ñ• i. prunes .x. tyme, &
wild Tyme ana. ‚Ñ• iiii. sene, dodder, ana. ‚Ñ•. & a half, suger .ii. pound, make a syrupe and claryfy it. A decoctyon therunto, take of violettes, sebesten, of Borage floures, ana. ‚Ñ•. & a half, of mirabola ‚Ä¢ s citrin, kebulis Indi. ana. ‚Ñ• iii. of rewbarbe . í i mak a decoction.

div.head: ¬∂Of a Quartayne in haruest. Capi. lxxxvii.
div.p:
AGaiÃÑst a quartaine of burnt coler in haruest, take ye rote of fennel, parcely, of bochers brome sperage, cinksoyle‚ñ™ of grasse, of Endiue, cychory, cyterach, mayden here tentworte, Hartes tounge‚ñ™ Lang ‚Ä¢ ebefe, Lentils, Acasia. ana. ‚Ñ• & a half prunes .xx. wine of pomegranates, a pound & a halfe, of suger .iii.l ‚Ä¢ . make a syrupe. A decoctioÃÑ herevnto take of violets .‚Ñ• iiii of borage flours
sebestene, cassia fistula, tamarindes ana. ‚Ñ• i. o ‚Ä¢ time, and wild Time, of both ‚Ä¢ ortes of sticados mirabolans citrinia Indi, the foure cold seades, M ‚Ä¢ lons, Gourdes, cucumers Pepons, ana. ‚Ñ•. of Prunes .xx. make a decoctyon.

div.head: ¬∂ Of a quartayne bredde of naturall melancholy Ca, lxxxviii.
div.p:
AGaynst the Feuer Quartayne bre ‚Ä¢ of melancholy natural. Take the rote of Fennell, of Perselye, of buchers brome, of sperage, of cinkesoyle, of Hartes tounge, of the rote of langedubefe, of hogges tounge the rote of an elder, walwor ‚Ä¢ , germaÃÑ der, ground Iuye, of both sortes of stychados, Calament, Organe, of the cold herbes, Melons, gourdes, Cucumers, PepoÃÑs ana. m.i. of violettes, of Borage floures, Ana. ‚Ñ• ii of Spikenarde .‚Ñ• iii. of the ioyce of borage .‚Ñ• i. of whit veniger, a pouÃÑd
of suger .iiii. pound, make a syrupe wt the decoctyon of .iii. pouÃÑd of germander, let the pacient Receiue the syrup with this decoction early and late.

AGaynst a quartayne Agewe. Take violettes, borage floures‚ñ™ sene, time, & epithime, ana. ‚Ñ• ii. Mirabolanes, citrin, Kebul ‚Ä¢ s Indi, Ana. ‚Ñ•. make a decoction and geue it to the pacient (yf he be stroÃÑg of nature) before the fyt.

div.head: A potion for a quartayne. Capi. lxxxix.
div.p: FOr a quartayne this potioÃÑ is good to pourge by litle & litle & is giuen froÃÑ thre days to .iii or froÃÑ iiii. to .iiii. as is nedful‚ñ™ for it purgith and disgestithe speciallye if it be wyth a coughe.

Take wylde tyme, calamint, blacke helebour, Sene, violettes, hysope, & oke or wall ferne. Ana. í i. & a halfe
of fenell, Lequoryse, of the rotes of Fennell, and smallage, ana. í and a halfe, let them be sodden and stande to settill that it maye clarifye, and take of the decoctyon .v. pound: and let it be made in a syrup ‚Ä¢ giue therof in a receptyon vnto the pacient .‚Ñ• ii. in the mornynge.

div.head: ¬∂ A confectyon of pylles to purge all corupt humores. Capi. lxxxx.
div.p: A Confectyon of pils wherwt humors are dissoluid, take the inner parte of coloquintida . í i. of agaricke í. & a half, of Baurach í i. of Liquoryse . í i. of Nettels sede roket royal, ana. í. and a half, staÃÑp them and make pilles.

div.head: ‚ùßOf heuynes or drousynes of the heade. Capi. lxxxxi.
div.p: A Certayne experiment agayns ‚Ä¢ the heuines of the heade. Take of Agaricke . í v. of the ioyce of wild Sage, Rewbarbe, Holworte, ana í i. whit suger . í ii. and a halfe, make pilles lyke to cyche Pese, and drynke one therof thryse in a weke, or els euery day till you haue made an end of al, it helpith in the middes but specyally in the ende without any daunger.
Take of cloues, macys, Nutmigges, Galingale, Dragons bloud anyse, comin ana. í i. as muche of spurge as of theÃÑ al and make a pouder.

div.head: The aphorismes of Hippocrates redacted vnto a certayne order, accordynge vnto y‚Ä¢ membres of a mans body, and the dyseases that may fall in any of them.
Of the disposityon of the head. Capi. prim.
div.p: VRyne troubled like vnto the water of an Oxe or horse signifieth paynes in the head.
Milke is euyll for them that haue the head ache,
If y‚Ä¢ paines be in ye nodle of ye head it is good to cut ye vaine in ye forhed
If any matter or water flowe out at his nose or eares whiche hath the head ache, it taketh away ye paines.

Whatsoeuer helthful man is sodeÃÑ ly payned in the head & therwith losyth
his voyce & routeth withall, he dyeth wythin seuen dayes, if an Agew take hym not.

div.head: Of the lethargye or forgetfulnes. Capi. ii.
div.p: To tremble in a lythargy is very euyll.

div.head: ‚ùß Of the payne in the heade called subeth. Ca. iii.
div.p: IN this disease paynfull sleape is mortal.

div.head: ¬∂Of to much watchynge. Cap. iiii.
div.p: Immoderat sleape or watching is very euyll.

div.head: ‚òûOf the Palsey. Capi. v.
div.p: PAlseys do commenly chance froÃÑ xl. yeres of age tyll .lx
It is hard to helpe a small palsey, but to heale a greuouse palsey it is ympossible.
It is no matter what kinde of spume or froth be about theyr mouthes which be strangled or haue thhe palsey, and be not yet dead.

div.head: ¬∂Of the madnesse callyd melancholia. Capi. vi.
div.p: A Swellynge or weaknesse endurynge a longe tyme bryngeth a maÃÑto a melancholy.
Peryllouse eruptons in al melancholyke dyseases, do signifye eyther the palsey a conuulsyon, blyndenesse or madn ‚Ä¢ sse.
The Hemorrhoydes be very good to such as be melancholyke.

div.head: ‚ùß Of Ragyng madnesse. Capi. vii.
div.p: IF he that is mad be takeÃÑ with a laxe or hidropsye, it is good
The Hemorrhoydes breaking out, take a way madnesse.
If a mad man vse to laughe it is a laudable signe, but yf he be verye sad, it is peryllouse.
If a mad man fynde ease in sleaping it is good, but if hys rage encrease, it is to be fearyd.

div.head: ¬∂Of the fallyng Euyll. Capi. viii.
div.p: THei which haue the falling euil in theyr childhod be oft healed, but if they be past .xxv. yere old, they dy for the most parte.
The changing of place time, and age curethe the falling euill in yong men.

div.head: ¬∂Of the diseases in the synowes. Ca. ix
div.p: ALl cold thynges be noyouse to the synowes, the bones, ye teth the braines & the mary in the backe, & vnto those al hote thynges be profitable and good.
A sodeyne Feuer healeth y‚Ä¢ craÃÑpe.
A convulsyon after sleape in an ague, is to be feared.
To be short breathyd in an ague is the signe of a convulsion.
A convulsyon or gripinges in the bely in sharpe agues, be very euil.
A convulsyon after the drynking of hellebore, is deadly.
To haue a convulsyon with a sore wounde is death.
A conuulsyon is perillouse to him that hath blede muche.
A convulsyon or yeskynge after a great inadityon be very euell.
If a dronken man lose his speche & haue a coÃÑuulsyoÃÑ he shal shortly die.
A convulsion cometh of immoderate fulnesse or emptinesse & so doth yeskynge.
Yeskinge, vomiting, a convulsioÃÑ or m ‚Ä¢ dnesse coming vpon hym yt is payn ‚Ä¢ d in the smal guttes are, to be fearyd.
The crampe or madnesse wt much watching, is very perillouse.
He that is taken with a sore convulsyon yf he lyue foure dayes shall e ‚Ä¢ kape.
A convulsyon after a purgatyon is very perillouse.

If a yonge man beinge fleshy be taken wyth a distension of the synowes in the Somer tyme. let hym be washed wyth cold water for ye doth
encrease the heate, and ye heate dothe asswage hys paynes.
In sore woundes a convulsion or distencyon be very euyll.

div.head: ¬∂Of the drousynes in the head. Capi. ‚Ä¢ .
div.p: TO dote or to be astonied after a blowe or stripe is, very euil,

div.head: ¬∂Of the membres being set awrye. Capi. xi.
div.p: IN a contynuall agew if the lyppes, the eyes, the browes or the nose stand awry, so that the pacyent can not heare or see and be therwith very weke, he shal dye shortly after.

div.head: ¬∂Of the disposicion of the eyes. Capi. xii.
div.p:
OF the tymes of ye yere if it chaÃÑ ce the winter to be drye and ye northwind to blowe, the springtime moyst with the southwynd, ye somer folowing there shal many be troubled with blernesse, but of the coÃÑtrary part if the wynter be moyst wyth muche southwind, & the springtime drye with northwindes, men shalbe
likewise vexed with dry blernisse.
If in autune, or Heruest there be muche drought, and northwyndes, it shal do good to moyst persoÃÑs and women, but other it shall vexe wyth drye blernes.
When the tymes of the yere be dry m ‚Ä¢ ny shall haue bler eyes.
The southwynde blowinge dayly for a season, wyl engender daselinge in the eyes.
Diseases of the eyes do cheflye rainge in somer.
In a continuall agewe, if the eyes be wrythen a syde, and the pacyent weake and cannot see, it is a pr ‚Ä¢ sent token of death.
In all kyndes of Feuers, and other diseases, voluntarye teares be laudable‚ñ™ but if they flowe contrary to the pacyentes mynd, they be to be fearyd.
It is very good‚ñ™ if he that is diseasyd in ye eyes be taken wt a sodeÃÑ lax.
All dyseasys in the eyes be healyd eyther by drinking of swete wynes, or with baths of whote water or lettyng of bloude or with a purgacioÃÑ.

If a man be seke marke hys eyes when he slepyth for yf anye whyte thynge appeare betwixt the eye liddes, and the pacient haue no greate laxe nor receyued any purgatioÃÑ before, is a terrible and deadly sygne.

div.head: ‚ùßOf the disposion of the eares. Capi. xiii.
div.p: WHosoeuer vseth to voyde choler, and in ye meane while waxeth defe, the laxe stoppeth, and of the contrary part, a sodeyne lax & deiectyon of choler taketh awaye defnesse.
To waxe defe in a continuall agew (the pacyent beinge weake of body) is a token of death.

Uoluntary bleding at the nose or
a sodaine lax dothe take awaye the de ‚Ä¢ nes which comyth of an ague.

div.head: ‚òûOf the dysposition of the nose. Capi. xiiii.
div.p: THey whose nostrilles be ful of superfluouse moystnesse, and haue also theyr nature or seade very watrish, be not helthful of body, and they that be contrary enioy continual helth.
Horsnesse and continuall fluxion of sneuil in old men, do in no meaÃÑs waxe rype.

A dry Somer wyth often northwynd and a moyst Haruest wyth ye southwind, doth engendre in ye next wynter the heade ake, ye coughe horsenesse, and much fluxyon of rewme by the nosthrils, but yf the Heruest be drye and the northwynd blowe, the rewme shall endure muche longer. Old men be often greuyd with fluxyon of rewme and ye coughe.

Muche rewme conteyned in the
stomake is changed within twenty days to playne matter.
All cold thinges as snow and yse, do engender distillatyons.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the bledinge at the nose. Capi. xv.
div.p: OLd men and children do ofte blede at the nose.
If it chance him that is seke of an agewe to blede, he shall haue a laxe in the decrease of his feuer.
He that waxeth deffe throughe an agewe & bledithe at the nose shal recouer his hearinge.
Who so is like to haue an apostem in ani of his ioyntes and in the meane while bleadeth at the nose is sure to recouer his helth.
If a woman whose floures be stopped do chance to blead at the nose it is a good sygne.
Bleding at the nose or eares taketh away the headake.

To haue the crampe or to dote
while the nose bledeth is an euyll sygne.

div.head: ¬∂ Of nesing. Capi xvi
div.p: IF a woman hauynge the mother, or beiÃÑg in paynes of child birth, chance to nese. it is very good.
Nesinge taketh away belchinge.

All nesing that cometh of the head is caused eyther of the brayne being hote, or the empti place of the heade being very moyst, for the ayre with in conteined brekith out throughe a narowe passage, and therby causeth the noyse.

div.head: ¬∂Of the disposions of the mouth & tong. Capi. xvii.
div.p: YOnge childreÃÑ and infantes be often troubled wyth vlcers in the mouthe, and to muche vomytinge.
Of al other men they which lispe, be most troubled with mani sieges, and laxes.

div.head: ¬∂Of the diseases in the teth. Capi. xviii.
div.p: IT is the sygne of contynuance in an ague, to haue much slimy matter about the tethe.
When the teeth begin to grow children are payned with feuers, crampes, and ytchinge of the gummes‚ñ™ & espicially in the growyng of the guÃÑ me teethe.

div.head: ¬∂Of the grefes in the throte. Ca. xix
div.p: OFtentimes diseases propre for the somer season do chance in autume, as the squinancy, shortnes of breth, and the paynes in the flape that couereth the wynde pype.
A suffocatyon chancinge to hym that hath an agew, and no swelling remayne in the throte, is a token of dethe.
If the squinancye fal downe to the lyghtes, and the pacient lyue seuen dayes, the fluxion wil turne to matter
If he that hath the squinancy do swell in the neckei, tis a good token for the fluxion is dryuen outward.
He that hath an agew not beinge able to turne hys necke, neyther to swallowe his meate, wtout a manifest swelling in the throte, shal short lye dye.

div.head: ‚òûOf the brest and lyghtes. Cap. xx.
div.p: TO haue the brethe somwhat stopped in an agew is an euyll token, for a convulsyon shall shortly folow, thei which haue swellyng in theyr backes before they be xiiii. yere old comyng of shortnesse of brethe, or a sore cough, shal shortly dye.

If it chance a droÃÑken man sodenly to fal spechlesse, he shall shortlye dye of a conuulsyon, excepte eyther he fall to an agew, or els he receyue his spech agayne at the houre when the surfyt is digestyd.

They which sodenly ar taken wt paynes in the head, & therwyth lose theyr speche & route, they dye shortly, if they be not taken wt an agew. Whosoeuer hath his braynes hurt any way, doth sodeÃÑly lose his spech.

div.head: ¬∂Of bloud spyttynge. Capi. xxi.
div.p: YOnge men be chieflye troubled wt spittyng of bloud, consumptyons, hote feuers, and the fallynge Euyll.
The spyttel in a continual Feuer beinge wane of colour, bloudy, stinkyng, or cholericke, is an euel tokeÃÑ.
He that spitteth frothy bloud is diseasyd in the lyghtes.
If he that spitteth bloud, spit therwith al filthye matter, it is an euyll sygne.
To vomit bloud wtout an agew is helthful, but in an ague peruicious

div.head: ¬∂Of the pleurisye. Capi. xxii,
div.p:
IF in the beginnyng of a Pleurysye the pacyent vse to spit, it shortneth
the disease, but yf it chance afward it prolongeth the paynes.
The Northwynd blowing a long season to geder, engendreth colykes coughes, and pleurisyes.
Pleurisyes, peripeunomyes, rewmes, and coughes do chiefli raygne in the wynter.
If he whiche hath the pleurisie, be not purged in .xiiii. dayes, the fluxyon wyl change to matter.
The pleurisy once changed to matter, if the pacieÃÑt be not purged with in fourty dayes after the brekinge furth of the matter, he shall fal to a consumptyon.
A sodeyne laxe folowing a pleurysie or a peripeunomy, is verye peryllouse.
They whose belchinge smellith ‚Ä¢ umwhat sharpe or tarte, be not geuen to the pleurisye.
The frenesye in a peripeunomye is an euil token.
Whosoeuer hauinge filthy matter in the voyd place of the stomake, or hauing the hydropsy, is laÃÑced or breÃÑ ned, yf all the matter or water issue furthe, it is present death.

div.head: ¬∂Of the consumpsion or ptisike. Cap. xxiii
div.p: AUtume or heruest is very yuill to theÃÑ which be in a consumption.
A drye somer with muche northewynd, and a moyst heruest wt southwyndes, do engendre in the wynter folowynge coughes and rewmes, & to dyuerse, consumptyons.
In consumptions purge downeward, and vpward.
They whiche be betwixt .xviii. & .xxv. be chieflye troubled with the ptisike.
If his spittell which hathe a consumpsition beinge cast vpon coles do stincke, and the heare fall of his heade, it is a signe of death.
A sodeyne laxe to him that is in a consumptyon and his heare fall o ‚Ä¢ is deadly.

Mylke is vnholsome to theÃÑ whiche haue the headake, or that be syke of any feuer, and to theÃÑ which hau ‚Ä¢ noyse and wynde in the hyer parte of ther belyes, and that haue cholerike decoctions in hote feuers, or yt haue lost muche of theyr bloude, & of the contrarye parte, it is good to such as haue a consumption wythout an agew, and also it may be ministred to them which haue agewes long tyme, if none of the abouesayd tokens do appere, & to such as haue bene longe seke of a consumption.
Aptisike or laxe with spittynge of fylthy matter yf the spittinge cease is deadly.

div.head: ¬∂Of the dispositions of the hert Ca. 24.
div.p: GReat brennynge in the stomake & prickynge about the h ‚Ä¢ rt is an euil token in an agew.

They which lose theyr strength of ‚Ä¢ entymes wythout manifest occasioÃÑ
‚Ä¢ hall dye sodenly.

div.head: ¬∂Of the Pappes. Capi. xxv.
div.p:
IF the Pappes of a woman whi
‚Ä¢ h is wt child of two do waxe lyttel, ‚Ä¢ he shall lose one child, and if it be ye right Pappe it is a man childe, and if it be the lyft a woman.
If a woman, that neyther is with child, nother hath brought furthe a child, haue milke in her pappes, she is past her Floures.
Bloude drawing to the pappes of a woman, is a signe of the frenesy.
If thou wilt stoppe the floures of a woman, put a great ventose vpoÃÑ her pappes.
Muche mylke yssuyng out of the tetes of a woman yt is with child, betokeneth the child to be very weake and feble, but if the pappes be hard the child is strong and helthful.

Lyke as the decreasing of the pappes
is a signe of the destructyon of the child, so the hardnes of the same signifieth great paynes, in the pappes, legges, knees, or eyes, and the lyfe of the child.

div.head: Of the stomake. Cap. xxvi.
div.p: THe stomacke is most hote in the wynter and springtyme and then also the slepes be longest.
Men can not wel away wt much meat in the somer and herueste, but meanly in the spring, and best of all in the wynter.
In all dyseases to be stedfast of mynd, and to be content wyth such thinges as be mynystred to hym, is a laudable sygne, but the contrarye is very euyl.
Drynke of wyne doth take away hunger.
If he whiche goeth very dry to bedde steppe, it is good.

If they which haue certayne murmuryng and wynd in theyr belyes,
haue greate paynes in the loynes, they shal haue moyst deiections, if ye wind do nether com furth nor great multitude of vryne, and al these do chance in feuers.
If in a laxe or vomyt suche thinges be purged as oughte to be purged, it doth ease the pacieÃÑt and it is nothing greuouse, but if no it chauÃÑ ceth contrary.
Let suche as can not easly vomit, be purged downewarde, but not in the somer.
In all kynde of diseases if blacke choler be purged vpward or downewarde wythout a medicyne, it is perillouse.
In the paynes of the small guttes callyd yl ‚Ä¢ aca, vomytynge, yeskynge, convulsyon, or dotynge be euyl.
A convulsion and yeskyng after a great purging, ar to be fearyd.
A sodeyne and voluntary vomiting, healeth hym that hath had a longe laxe.
Yeskynge is good to him whiche hath a heate & swelling in the liuer.

div.head: ¬∂Of the diseasys in the liuer. Capi. xxvii
div.p: AN agew taketh away ye grefe and paynes in the lyuer.
A wounde in the braynes, hert, midrife, smal guttes, stomake, or lyuer is deadly.
If he whose lyuer mattreth be breÃÑ nid and therout issue pure and whit matter, he shal eskape, but if it be lik dregges he shall shortly dye.
Many diseases proper, to ye somer do chance in haruest, as quartaines and Hydropsyes engendryd in the splene.

If he whiche hath the dropsye be woundyd, it is harde to hele hym. Whosoeuer hath grypinges about the hauel, and paynes in the loynes and cannot be helped bi purgatioÃÑs
or otherwise shal fal to a dry hidropsye.
The coughe goinge before the hidropsye is euyl, but in the hydropsy much worse.
If they which he splenetike, haue a blody flux which wil long continewe, they fall to the hydropsye, or theyr meat shal cume throughe theÃÑ vndygestyd and so they dye.
A bloudy fluxe, an hidropsy or madnesse after a frenesy, are laudable.
Whoso haue theyr lyuer full of water, and it breake downwarde to the bely, it is death.
If he that hath an agew be taken wi ‚Ä¢ h the yelow iandes ye .vii. the .ix. the .xi. or .xiiii. day, it is laudable, yf the right side waxe not hard, but if it do, it is contrary.
An agew taketh away the paines vnder the syddes, yf it be withoute great heate and swellyng.

div.head: ¬∂Of the gaule and splene. Capi. xxviii.
div.p: IF the yelow Iaundes, chance in an agew before the seuenth day, it is euyl.
They whiche haue the yelow iandes be not ful of wynd.
If ther lyuer whyche haue the yelowe ye iandes be hard, it is an euil sygne.
A bloudy flux is good to th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y‚Ä¢ be splenetyke.

div.head: ¬∂ Of al kynd of fluxyons. Cap. x ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
div.p: IN a laxe dyuerse kyndes of „Äà‚óä„Äâ be good, except they change to „Äà‚óä„Äâ as be euyll.

Blacke sieges lyke to fylthy b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ude bein ‚Ä¢ voluntary be wounder ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l euyl wh ‚Ä¢ rther they be wt an „Äà‚óä„Äâ or wtout an agew, and ye de ‚Ä¢ ker to our they haue, the worse they be, but yf these sieges com throughe a p ‚Ä¢ rgacion they be more laudable, „Äà‚óä„Äâ & althoughe they be of diuerse coloures the be not euyl.

To haue a siege of playne m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
cholye,
or to perbreake the same in y‚Ä¢ beginnyng of any disease is deadly

Whosoeuer is brought weake ether by some greuouse disease or siknes of longe contynuaÃÑce, or by wouÃÑ des receyued, or eny other waye, and thervpon haue a syege of melancholie like to blacke bloud he shal doutlesse dey the day after.
A bloudy fluxe begynnynge with a melancholike siege, is deadly.
Lytle peaces ‚Ä¢ f fleshe appearinge in a bloudye sie ‚Ä¢ e, be tokens of present death.
Uayne desyre to the stole in a woman wt child, killeth the child.
Tart or sharpe belching sodenlye chancing to hym whose meate cometh throughe him indigestid, is veri good.
In loÃÑg continuaÃÑce of a bloudye flux, to absteine froÃÑ meate, is veri euyl & if it be wt an ague much wors
A bloudy flux is good to such as be splenetike.
A sodayne bloudy fluxe after a sincer or cleane siege, is to be fearyd.
If a great laxe chance in a whyte morfewe, it taketh away ye disease.
Frothy sieges in a fluxe, do declare the flegme to come from the head.
It is an euell token in a sharpe agewe, to haue a convulsion, or painful gripinges in the bely.
Paynes in the hyer partes of the bely, be more gentle & of leasser perill then they whiche be in the lower parte.
If he whiche hath the strangurye, be takeÃÑ with the paynes in the smal guttes callyd iliaca, he shall dye wt in seuen dayes, excepte a feuer take hym with muche flux of vryn.

div.head: ‚òû Of the fundament. Ca. xxx.
div.p: IF the Hemorrhoydes chaunce to such as be melancolike mad, or frentike, it is laudable.

If he that hath longe tyme had the hemorrhoydes be healyd, & not one
left open, it is to be feared least he fall to a consumptyon or hidropsye
The hemorrhoydes be very good to such as haue a melaÃÑcholike madnesse, or great grefe in the raynes.

div.head: ¬∂Of the disposicyon of raynes. Capi. xxxi.
div.p: THey which haue the paynes in the raynes after .xl. yeres of age, can not be healyd.
They whose vryne is full of grauel be seke of the stone, eyther in the raynes, or in the bladder.
Dyseases in the raynes and bladder, are skant curable in old men. Lytle bladders or bubles in a maÃÑs vryne, do betoken paynes in the raynes, and longe diseasys.
The hyer part of the vryne fattye & thicke, is a sygne of paynes in the raynes and sume greuouse disease.

If the aboue sayd tokens appeare in suche as be seke in the raynes, & also haue sore paines in the muscles of ye backe, if the paynes be inwarde
it signifieth an apostem in the inner partes, but if they be outward the apostem shalbe ther also.
Much flegme conteyned betwixt the stomacke and the midrife, hauiÃÑg no way to the bely, is sone dissoluid if it issue by the vaynes to the bladder, and thence furth in vryne.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the diseases in the bladder. Cap. 32.
div.p: IN moyst and wete season, longe agewes fluxes, rottenesse, ye falling euyl, the squinancy, and the palsye do cheflye raygne, but contrarye in dry seasons, coÃÑsumptions, blearnes goutes, straÃÑguryes & bloudy fluxes
Children be often greued wt paynes in the throte, and fallinge of the iawes, wormes in the bely, & stranguryes.

Old men haue moost comenlye these diseasys, shortnesse of brethe, rewme, the coughe, the straÃÑguri, difficulty of vryne, goutes, daselinge in the head, paynes in ye raynes, palses
in theyr bodies out of iust temperanse, y‚Ä¢ ytche, watchinges wt moystnesse in the bely eyes and nosthriles dulnesse of syght, and hering.
If his water that is seke of an Ague be litell in quantitie thicke and ful of cruÃÑmes, & th ‚Ä¢ rvpoÃÑ his vryne folowe much in quantitie and thine it is very good,
Whosoeuer in an ague hath his water troubled lyke to the vryne of an oxe or cowe, hath or shortly shall haue the headake.
In such diseasys as shalbe endyd the seuenth daye, ther shall appeare in the pacyentes vryne a red cloude the fourth daye with other reasonable tokens.
Uryne whyte and cleare is not laudable, and especially in them whych be frentike or do ‚Ä¢ ing.

They which be lyke to haue an apostem in theyr ioyntes, be deliuerid therof by much vryne white & thick
as that which cometh from such as haue ben iiii. dayes seke of an ague
Bloud or matter in the vrine doth declare vlcers, and biles, eyther in ye raynes or blad ‚Ä¢ er.

Lytell peces „Äà‚óä„Äâ fleshe and heares in the vryne co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ rom the raynes.
Contentes lyk ‚Ä¢ branne in ye vrine signifye a Pocke or Scabbe in the bladder.

They which p ‚Ä¢ sse bloud haue a vayne broken in th ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ynes.

If they which „Äà‚óä„Äâ bloud or cromes, or els hau ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ he ‚Ä¢ tranguri, if the paynes be bene ‚Ä¢ h the beli about the share, the disease is in the bladder.
Grauell in the vryne betokeneth ye stone in the bladder.
He that pisseth bloude or matter, & he in whose vrine skales do appere, or the water haue a stroÃÑg smel, hath vlcers in the bladder.

Whoso hath pustules or welkes in his yarde, and if they breake and
the matter runne oute, they shalbe shortly hole.
To pisse muche in the night, dothe betoken a lytlel siege.
The strangury chanceth to that parson which hath a hote swellinge in the fundament, or matrix, and to hym whose reynes do matter, & yesking euer foloweth the heate & swellyng in the lyuer.
Diseases in the raynes and blader, are hard to heale in old men.
ConteÃÑtes in the botome of the vrine lyke vnto thicke branne, signify the disease longe to continue.
If the water do appeare vnlike of substance, it betokeneth great mystemperaÃÑce, for diuersitye of humors within the body.
Drinking of wyne, healeth ye straÃÑ gurye, and hym yt cannot holde hys water, & it is also good to let bloud of the inner vaynes about ye ancle.

div.head: ¬∂Of the membr ‚Ä¢ s of generatyon in men. Capi. xxxiii.
div.p: LYkewyse in men, eyther for the raritie of the bodye, the spirites goo out, so that the seede caÃÑ not come to his due place: or for the thiknesse therof the humour cannot get furthe, neyther wax hote for the coldnes, and so it heapeth in yt place or els ye same thyng cometh of great heate.
A bone a gristel, a synow, and the the toppe of the yard beinge cut, wil nether grow nor ioyne together.

div.head: ¬∂Of the membres of generation in women. Ca. xxxiiii
div.p: IF the wynter be moyst and warme & the southwind blow, the spriÃÑg time dry wt northwyndes, those women that be then with child shall of euery lyght occasyon lose theyr children, & the children then borne shalbe weake and seckely, wherfore they shal eyther dye strenght wt, or els al theyr lyfe tyme be, fayntye and full of diseasys.
If a woman with child must ned ‚Ä¢ be purged, let that be from ye fourth moneth to the seuenth, yet those suÃÑ what leasse, but before foure & after seuin let theÃÑ receyue no purgacions
The suffumigation of swete odurs doth bring furth the floures, & is good for dyuerse other thinges if it dyd not cause ye head to be drousi.
Lettynge of bloud dothe kyll the child, but the nyer ye byrthe the more perillouse it is.
If a woman wt child be taken with any greuouse disease, it is death.
The fluxyon of the floures taketh a way vomiting of bloud.
If the floures stoppe it is good to blede at the nose.
It is perillouse for a woman with child to haue a great laxe.
Nesynge is very good to her that hath the moder, or that trauaylethe of childbyrth.

She whose flours be euil colourid
or that kepe not theyr comyn cour ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ had nede to take a purgatyon.

If thou woldest know whether ‚Ä¢ woman hath conceyuyd or no, geu ‚Ä¢ her water and hony myngled together to drinke wheÃÑ she goeth to slepe and if she fele grypinges and paynes in her belye she is with childe, i ‚Ä¢ she fele non she is not.
A woman whiche hath conceuyd a male is well colouryd, but if it be a female, it is contrary.

Those women whiche be very smal and leane before they conceiue, shal lose one child before thei wax grose, Those wemen which beinge meane of body, do lose theyr children the secoÃÑd or thyrd moneth without manifest occasyon, haue the closures of theyr wombes ful of fylthy matter, wherfore they cannot susteyne the weyght of ye child, but sodeÃÑly breke.

They whiche be verye fat cannot conceyue tyl they wax leane, for the
‚Ä¢ outh of theyr matrix is stopped ‚Ä¢ p with fatnesse.
If thou wylt prouoke the floures ‚Ä¢ ause the woman to nese, and in the ‚Ä¢ eane while stop her nose & mouth
They whiche be wyth childe haue ‚Ä¢ heyr wombes closed vp.
If a woman with childe be taken wyth an agew, and waxe very hote, without manifest occasion, she hath great paynes in childebyrthe, or els ‚Ä¢ he loseth her child with perill of her ‚Ä¢ wne lyfe.

If a convulsyon, and fayntnesse ‚Ä¢ ake a womaÃÑ in ye tyme of her flou
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, it is perillouse.
If the floures haue to much yssue ther do ensue dyuerse diseases, & yf they be stopped ther foloweth great grefe in the wombe.

If a woman hath not conceyued, & thou wilt know whether she shal conceyue or no‚ñ™ let her be well coueryd with clothes, & beneth let a suffumigacion
be made of hote things and odoriferous, for if the smel com vp throughe her body to the nose & mouth, be sure yt she is not barayne of hir selfe.
If a woman with childe haue her flours, it is impossible ye child shuld be helthfull.
The floures stopping wt an ague or great cold, and the woman lothe her meate, say she is wyth child.

The matrix cold and grosse, or veri moyst, is not apt to conceyue, for ye seed is therin quenched & distroyed. Likewise if it be dry and very hote, for theÃÑ is the seed lost for lacke nourishment, but they whose matrix is of a meane temperature be pleÃÑtifull & do often conceyue, if yu wilt know more rede aboue in ye disposion of ye Pappes.

div.head: ¬∂Of the disposyon of the outward membres Capi. xxxv.
div.p:
IF two great grefes do happen in
diuerse meÃÑbres at one tyme, the gre ‚Ä¢
ter taketh away the leasse.
Paynes in the knees and loynes, or grypynges in the bely coming vpoÃÑ hym that hath non agew, do sygnifye that he shulde be purged downe warde.
In paynful feuers apostemes do often happen about the knees and chekes.
The siknesse shall chiefly remaine in that place which was greuyd before it beganne.
The ioyntes of such as haue had a feuer for a long season, shal ake & be ful of pustules.

Great paynes & swellynges in the ioyntes wt any brekinge or issue, do signifie that the goute or craÃÑpe shal folow, and many be remedied wyth much washyng wt cold water, for yt doth extenuat the humor and take a way the paynes, for a meane colde extinguisheth.
Letting of bloud doth vtterly take a way such paynes as begynne at ye backe, & theÃÑce remoue to the armes. Enuches be neuer bald nor gouty.
Women haue neuer the goute as longe as they haue theyr floures.
A childe hath neuer the goute vntil he hath knowen a woman.
All kynde of goutes (if the inflaÃÑ mation be quenchid) wythin fourty dayes, do end.
All goutes do chieflye reygne in springtyme and haruest.
If the hippe bone fall out of his place after a long sciatica, ther shall muche matter folowe, or the legge will consume away, and the pacient shall halt, except he be brennyd.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the Feuers and Agues. Capi. xxxvi.
div.p: THe siknesse it self, & the time of ye yere do playnly declare the tyme of the fyttes, the chefe time of the disease, & the order in y‚Ä¢ fittes.

Old men be neuer troubled wyth
„Äà1 page missing„Äâ
sore agewes because theyr bodyes be cold.
All sharpe diseasys are iudged in fourtene dayes.
Quartanes in somer be very short in Autume muche longer, in winter longest of all.
It is muche better that he whyche hath a convulsyon be takeÃÑ wyth an agew, then he which hath an agewe be taken wyth a convulsyon.

If his fleshe that hath a sore ague do eyther fall nothynge away at al or decay very much it is euil for the fyrst betokenith long contynuance of the disease, and the other great wekenesse in the person.
At the beginning and endynge of an agew, al thynges be of more streÃÑ gthe then in the chefe part therof.

In al diseases they be in leasse ieopardy to whose nature age, accustoÃÑ, or time of the yeare the sicknes doth agre, then they wyth whome it doth
in no poynt agree.
Wh ‚Ä¢ n the somer is not vnlike to the springe tyme you shall loke for muche sweting in al agewes.
In dry seasons ther shall reygne diuerse sore agewes.
All dyseases in the haruest season be perillouse and deadlye, but in the springtyme most gentyl and easy.

In the somer these do chiefly reygne, contynual and brenynge agews tertyan and quartayne feuers, vomyting, laxes, blernesse with vlcers in the mouthe and pryuy membres. A cold stifnesse chanciÃÑg the sixt day in any feuer doth take away all iudgmente.
All feuers which do not intermite and geue ouer the thyrde day be perillouse, but if the paciente haue no fyte that day ther is no ieope ‚Ä¢ dy.
If great coldnesse take hym whyche is veri weke thrugh a contynuall agew it is deadly.
If in a contynuall agew the outward membres be very cold and the inwarde partes hote and drye, it is a token of death
If in an agew pustules and paynes chaunce in the ioyntes, it is a signe that the pacient fedeth wel.

In a contynuall Feuer, yf the lyppes, the eyes, the Nose or the mouthe be wrythen and out of fashyon, so that the pacient can not se nor here and therwith all hys bodye be weake, it is a sygne that death is at hand.
A sodeyne laxe or dotage in a continuall feuer is deadly.
An apostem which doth not breake at the fyrst iudginge daye in a Feuer, doth signifie the longe contynuance of the dysease.
Uoluntary teares in agewes be laudable, but they whiche flowe agaynst the pacyentes wyll be to be fearyd.
Al Agewes with swellinge in the foundament be euyl except such as endure but one day.
If he which hath an agew do sweate very muche and the disease contynew it is euyl, for it betokeneth loÃÑg syknesse and abundance of humors
He that hath a convulsyon or discencion in ye synowes, and thervpoÃÑ an agew, is sodeynly delyuered.
A tertyan not endid in seuen fittes shall contynue longe.
The yelowe iaundes comyng vpoÃÑ hym that hath a Feuer before the seuenth day is perillouse.
To be affrayde in his sleape, or to haue the cramp is euill.
To be shorte brethyd in an agew is the sygne of a convulsyon.
Soryful syghes in sharpe agewes be to be fearyd.

They which haue the quartaine haue seldome convulsyons, and yf he which hath a convulsion fal to a
quartayne he shalbe deliuerid from his conuulsyon.

If he whiche hath an agew swette in these dayes folowing it is verye good, the thrid, the .v.vii, ix.xi.xiiii.xvii.xxi‚ñ™xxvii, xxxi.xxxiiii. for ye swetes do iudge ye feuer, but if they be otherwyse, they declare longe contynuance of ye disease & great paynes.

div.head: ¬∂ Of the diete to be obserued in agues. Capi. xxxvii
div.p: IN al diseases of long coÃÑtinuance the pacyent most vse lytle meate, & exquisite, but in sharpe diseasis yt is perillouse, yet to eate to lytell or to much be both euyl.

Secke m ‚Ä¢ n do more often erre in vsynge lytel meate, then in that diet whiche is sumwhat larger, wherby they be ofte hurt, yea and to such as be in helth small fare, and exquisite diete, is very perillouse, because thei easly erre therin.

Unto extreame diseases extreme
cures be necessary.

When the dysease is most extreme and sharpe the pacyent shal by and by haue woÃÑderful paynes, wherfore he most vse most smal and thin diet & as the disease is from extreme paynes so most the diet amend.
WheÃÑ ye seknesse is most vyoleÃÑt then most the pacieÃÑt vse least meate of al.
The phisicion most marke well whyther the pacyent vsynge suche small dyet may endure to the state & strengthe of the dysease, or whyther the paynes wyll fyrst asswage or no

If the siknesse in the beginnynge be most feruent, then most the pacicyent vse lytell meate, but yf the siknes be afterwarde most vyolent the pacyentes meate most be sumwhat before diminished, but in the beginning he most fede well that he may be able to abyde the dysease.

The pacyent most forbeare meate in the fyttes, & especially in suche agewes yt do intermyt & come bifits.
Amonge al other old meÃÑ may best a way wt fastiÃÑg, theÃÑ such as be of middell age, after yong men, and worse of al children & especially such as be quicke and lusty.

Such as grow, haue much naturall heate within them & therfore do require much meate, whyche yf they haue not theyr bodyes do sone coÃÑsume, but coÃÑtrary litel meate wyl ‚Ä¢ erue old men, because they haue but lytle natural hete whiche wt much meate is sone queÃÑched, & therfore thei haue not so feruent Agues because theyr bodyes be cold.

The stomake & inward partes be most hote in winter & springetime, wherfore men most then fede better, for ye inward heate theÃÑ being muche doth requyre much meat & for a profe therof marke ye ages & ye chaÃÑpioÃÑs Moyst meates be best of al to such as be sike of agues, & chiefly to childreÃÑ, & to such as haue beÃÑ acustomed
like meates.

You must marke whether you shal geue them meate onse or twyse, and to whome you must geue more, to whome lesse, and suÃÑwhat you moste bere wyth the tyme of the yere, the coÃÑ trey, the age of the person, and wyth the accustomed vse.
In somer and autume men maye skarce awai with much meat, but in the wynter best of all, and meane in the sprynge.
To such as haue theyr siknesse bi certayne fyttes in order, you shal geue nothyng, nether adde nor dimynishe afore the tyme of iudgynge.

div.trailer: ¬∂ Here end the Aphorismes of Hyppocrates, set in order for euery membre, and translatyd out of latyn into Englyshe by Humfre Lloyd.

div.head: A Boke conteynyng the names of the coÃÑpound medecines, which be good for all ky ‚Ä¢ de of dyseases that maye chance in any membre of mans bodye, in readyng of whych boke I would the geÃÑtle reader shuld be admonished of one thynge, which is yt I do comenly through al this boke vse the latyn names, & haue not translatyd ye same to ye Englyshe tongue, beinge mouyd therunto, because that many of them he suche that they caÃÑ not be wel Englished, and also t ‚Ä¢ at the Apothecaryes which haue such medicynes to sel do comenly vse the Latyne or rather Arabike, and Barbarouse termes, and not the Englyshe n ‚Ä¢ mes therof, vpon which consideracions I thought it best to vse the same throughe all this present boke.
¬∂ For al diseasys in the head. Capi. i.
div.p: THese confections folowyng do not suffer the heares to wax hore & gray electuarium de aromatibus, coÃÑfectio alharif, oleuÃÑ costinum and de alchana.

These be verye good for all diseases in the brayne, the electuarye of Perles, Triacle dyatessoron and
the confection of muske.

These comfort the brayne, aromaticum rofa
rum : maius aromaticum. dyambra, galie elephaÃÑgine & pillule stomatice.
These purge the brayne, the confectyon alphescera, & pillule elephangene, Oximell squillitike openeth ye opilatyon of the brayne.
The infusion of hyera healeth the melancolike paynes of the head.

These be good for the falling euil, confectio de musco, thiriaca diatessaron, confectio alfescera, syrupus sticados, acetum and oximel squilliticum, vnguentum de bdellio, oleuÃÑ de cucumere asmino, de lapide gagatis, de piperibus and philosophoruÃÑ. CoÃÑfectio alharif & kebuli coÃÑditi, be very good for al diseasis in ye senses
These purge ye instrumentes of ye senses, pillule elephangine stomatiche‚ñ™ aggregate and pillule lucis maiores and minores.
Hyerapicra purgeth al cold diseasis of ye head, so doth hiera hermetis, hieralogodioÃÑ rufi, & pillule aggregate
The cold diseases of the head are healyd wyth the confectyon of water and hony.
These confectyons ensuynge are good for all paines in the head, oximell squillitike, infusyon of Hyeratrociskes of cr ‚Ä¢ o: oyle Anet, oyle of Laurell, of spiknard, of elder & oyle of wild cucumer,
The infusion of hyera clensith the head, so do pillule stomatice and pillule aggregate maiores.
Hyera hermetis purgeth the hemicran, and pillule alhaÃÑdach an eÃÑplayster of mustard and oyle of euforbium heale the same.
The electuary of rosys purgithe the head ache of an hote cause, and so do pillule alhandach.

These heale the turne or daselynge in the head & eyes the confection of
muske a sharpe syroupe of citrones or of prunes, vinegre or oximel squllitike, but these purge the same hamech, electuarye of Roses, confectio psilii, hyera hermecis, and hieralogodion ruffi.

div.head: For the paynes & diseases in the eares. Ca. ii.
div.p: OYle of bytter almondes, oyle of peches and of beeÃÑ, ar good for al paynes & noyse in the eares.
Oyle of of Spiknard is good for wynd in the eares.

div.head: ¬∂For al diseases in the eyes. Ca. iii.
div.p: THe elec ‚Ä¢ uarie of Roses purgeth the superfluites whiche descend to ye eyes, also oleum Philosophorum is good for watry eyes.
Pillule de yera, and trifera persica purge al diseasis of the eyes & make cleare the syght.

div.head: ¬∂For al diseases in the nose and face. Ca. 4
div.p: OYle of wild Cucumer takethe away the steÃÑche in the nose and oleum Philosophorum openeth the oppilatyons of the same.
A syrupe of Popy and diacodion wt pillule contra catartum, purge & heale all weles whiche be vpon the nose and face.
These clense all foule colour, and difformitie of the face, diacucurma, diamorosion, diacodion, trifera minor, coÃÑfectio rauedseni & alkakengi, trochiskes of Roses & of rewbarb ‚Ä¢ .

div.head: For al diseasis in the mouth & throte. Ca. v.
div.p: FOr an Apostem in the throte dyamozoÃÑ and dyacaridoÃÑ be very good

These confections folowinge be good for them whyche cannot take their breath, the confectioÃÑ of muske loche of squilla, loche of pyne, loche ad Asma, Loche Alfescera, dyasulphur, philoniuÃÑ, the confection of perles, and alchermes.
Diacodyon and a syrupe of popie heale a rewme and coughe, so do pilbule contra catarrhum.
Uyneger squillitike healeth roten and lose gummes.
Oyle of swete Almondes and of sisami taketh away the asperitie and roughenesse of the throte.
Oyle of grysomyle taketh awaye all impedimentes of the tonge.

These confectioÃÑs make the mouth to haue a swete smel or odour ye electuarie of atomatikes & of perles, of citrones, the confectyoÃÑ of xiloaloes, aromaticum muscatum, aromaticuÃÑ nardinum‚ñ™ trifera saracenica, a syrupe of the pilling of orenges, mellicrat of orenges, trochiskes of gallia muskata, & sufuf xiloaloes, aromaticum, pillule dyarhodon.
An electuary or syrupe of peches, Peches condite, trochiskes of xiloaloes, take awaye all stenche in the mouth.
Dyatryonpipereon taketh awaye all belching.
A iulep of iniubes healeth al horsnesse.
Diacalamentum, philonium, diacyminuÃÑ and a syrupe of myntes do vtterly stoppe al paynfull and cold yeskyng.

These confectyoÃÑs of muske, ti ‚Ä¢ iaca diatesseron sirupus of sticados, the cerote of alexander, oyle of pip ‚Ä¢ r and oleum philosophoruÃÑ, & hyerahermetis, wt hieralogodioÃÑ do purge the same wounderful well.

Let hym that hath an old & paynfull coughe vse these, Dianisum, athanasia mag: & if his brest be full of matter, these be good, dyasulphure, loch de pino, lochsanum with syrupes of myrte, of licori ‚Ä¢ e‚ñ™ of Calamente, of prunes, of iniub ‚Ä¢ s, of Ysope, and these do extenu ‚Ä¢ te the grosse humores loch ad asma & susuf ad Asma, and yf they caÃÑnot slepe take a syrupe of Popie.

For a coughe of a hote cause tak ‚Ä¢ loche of popie, loch ad caliditatem a iulep of violetes, and a syrupe of ye same, wt the sirupe contra catarrhuÃÑ, but if it be a dry coughe, take a syrupe of tereniabine & of popie, loch bonum and loch of almondes.
Pillule de agarico & pillule ad omnes morbos catachi, do purge ye matter of an old coughe.
Lochsanum and expertum or a syrupe of iniubes take away horsnes that cometh of cold flegme.
Oyle of Cartamus of nucis indice, of sisami, do clarifi the voice, and so doth vinegre squillitike.
Musa acnea, oleum philosophoruÃÑ, be good for the toth ake, and acetuÃÑ squilliticum fasteneth the teeth.

div.head: ¬∂ For the morphew yelow iaundes and al other deformyties of the skyne. Capi. vi
div.p:
THese confectyons make the skyne well colouryd, electuarium de aromatibus, confectyon of
quinces, confectio anacardina, algarif syrup of fumitory, oyle of saffroÃÑ of cost trifera galeni, & the confectioÃÑ of maÃÑna.
Unguentum alfesericuÃÑ and oleuÃÑ de cucumere asinino, taketh away ‚Ä¢ the roughnesse of the skynne, hamech purgeth al diseases which be in y‚Ä¢ skynne and ye elephancye.

If you wil haue your skynne smothe & cleane, vse these trifera muskata, dyacucurma, diamorusioÃÑ oyle of been, of Cherystones, of citrones of elder, of serpeÃÑtes, of egges, of whete of iuniper and oyle of ashe.
UnguentuÃÑ sericinum is good for to cause the skynne to growe.
UnguentuÃÑ rosaruÃÑ, violaruÃÑ, vngueÃÑ tuÃÑ ceruse, oleuÃÑ de iunipero & defraxino, trochiskes of arsenicke do heale wyldfyre and ringwormes.

These confectyoÃÑs heale the yelow iandes, confectio rauedseni, trifera persica coÃÑfectio de psilio, trochiskes
„Äà1 page missing„Äâ
of Rosis, of reubarbe, of camphory and of enpatori electuariuÃÑ rosaruÃÑ, sirupus de fumoterre & pillule inde.
Hyeralogodion ruffi, hamech, coÃÑ fectio epithini, pillule inde, Pillule fetide, do purge all matter of morphew and leprousy.
Syrupus de fumoterre, and epithimi, oyle of iunyper, vnguentum alfesericon. do heale the leprousy.
Unguentum aragit, oleum de been, de nucleis cerasorum, de granis cittaÃÑguloruÃÑ, do take away the spott ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the morphew.
UngueÃÑtum alhariel, taketh away the spottes of the skynne.
Pillule Collequintide do purge an old morphewe.
Pillule aggregate minores purge and take away al ytching and skratchynge.
These be good for scabbes, oleuÃÑ nucuÃÑ, vngueÃÑtuÃÑ cerusae & alphesericuÃÑ.

div.head: ¬∂For al diseases in the stomake. Capi. vii.
div.p: AN hard apostem of the stomake is mollifyed wt moyst hisop, & a cerote of ysop of galenes descriptyon, dyaquilon wyth the emplaster of oribasius, and oyle of masticke.
These do styre vp appetite ones lost, aromaticum rosatum the confectyon of quynces, of alchanzi and of orenges, trochiskes of Myrabolanes do encrease appetite wounderfull well.

These confectyons do make good digestyon, dyarodon, acondite of orenges, aromaticum nardinuÃÑ, and rosatum, hyeralogodyon ruffi, pillule stomatice, rosatum maius, diaciminum, diambra, diatrioupipereoÃÑ kebuli co ‚Ä¢ diti, a condite of quinces of buglosse, sufuf xiloalo ‚Ä¢ s, sufuf aromatuÃÑ, vineger squillitike, trochiskes of rose, pi ‚Ä¢ lule elephangine, pillule de turbithe.
The confection de galanga, diaciminuÃÑ oximel squilliticuÃÑ be good for belchinge that cometh of sharpe matter.
Confectio de aromatibus comforteth the stomake that cannot abyde the smel of meates, so doth aromaticum rosatum, and gariofilatum, and syrup deminta.
Athanasia magna, lochbonuÃÑ aqua mellis sirupus de liqueritia pillule de agarico trochisci aneti, do cleÃÑ se ye stomake.
Loch de papanere, loche de squilla loche alphescera, syrupus de ysopo, sufuf ad tussim antiquem, oleum de ketri & de lillio take away al paynes in the stomacke.
Lochsan ‚Ä¢ m clenseth al filthy matter out of the stomacke.
Loch de amigdalis healeth the vehement drynesse of the longes and stom ‚Ä¢ ke.

Sirupus de prassio de thimo de
kesmes heale all colde disease of the stomake.
Oleum de cartamo & oximel squilliticum, sirup de ‚Ä¢ upatorio, ‚Ä¢ roch de absinthio open ye opilations of the stomake.
These confections take away ye asperitie or roughnesse of the stomake
Loch ad calliditatem, iulep vio: iulep iniub: syrupus cucurbite, sirupe de prunis, sirupus de granatis, oleum papaner: oleum violace.
Electuarum de aromatibus, de g ‚Ä¢ mmis, confectio xiloaloes, oxim ‚Ä¢ l squilliticum, and oleum nardinum, heale al diseases of the stomake whiche com of grosse and slymy flegme.

All ventosites and inflations of the stomake ar cured wyth these confectioÃÑs, electuariuÃÑ de aromatibus, de citro alxicostuÃÑ, troch de spodio: vngueÃÑtuÃÑ rosaruÃÑ cerotum saÃÑdalinuÃÑ coÃÑ fectio de galaÃÑga de ziÃÑzibere, philonium, diacyminuÃÑ, trifera muscata, diacucurma,
diamorusioÃÑ secacul condituÃÑ, pillule aggregate maiores.

These confectyons coÃÑfort a weake stomake and cause good digestion, electuaryes de aromatibus, de citro de granis mirthi, de persicis, de sorbis, confectyons xiloaloes, alkinzi, de citonus, aromaticum rosatum, gariofilatum, nardinum, trifera galeni, yeralogodioÃÑ ruffi kebuli coÃÑditi emb ‚Ä¢ ici coÃÑditi, citonia persica condita, zuecharum rosatum, syrupes de piris, de citoniis, de corticibus citri, de granis mirthi de albela, de absinthio, de fumotere mellicrata de citro debuglasso decitoniis, rob de piris, de citoniis, de graÃÑatis, fructibus, de aggresta, trochiskes, de gallia de rosis, ramich de absinthio, sufuf xiloaloes, sufuf diarodon, sufuf aromaticum, pillule elephangine aggregate, stomatice, diarodon, Cerotum Alexandri, emplasters, dyafinicon, stomaticum,
de Gallia, de Fermento, Oyles, de stincho de Citoniis, maluinum, myrtilorum masticum, costinum, and of elder.

Let him yt is payned in the stomake wyth multitude of hote and sharpe humours, vse these dyarodoÃÑ galeni, acetum squilliticum infusio de Hyera, pillule elephangine but if the paynes come of cold humoures these be very good confectio anacardina, philonium Musa acnea, Athanasia magna oleuÃÑ de Cartamo and de kerua.

These mitigate the vehemente hete of ye stomake, electuarium de persicis, confectio de acetosa, de Pruuis, trifera persica, iulep rosatuÃÑ. syrupus de Persicis, de portulaca trochiskes de CaÃÑphora de Sandalis, Sufuf Dyarodon rob de ribes de berberys, de sumache & demoris.

Agaynst the humiditie of the stomake
vse aromaticum maius rosatum, gario ‚Ä¢ ilatum, coÃÑfectio de cynamomo, trifera saracenica, diacucurma, dyamorusioÃÑ, emblici conditi, trochisci dyarodon.
These confections purge the stomake, hierapigra galeni, hiera hermetis‚ñ™ pillule elephaÃÑgine, and agregate fetide and sebellie, electuarium alharif.
For the inflammatyon of the stomake, take sirupus de succo acetose de agresta, de pomis, and sirupus acetosus t ‚Ä¢ reniabin.
These comfort a cold stomake, syrupus de menta, de thimo, secaniabiÃÑ de calamento, mellicratuÃÑ coÃÑdituÃÑ.

Let him that vomiteth ouermuche vse these aromaticum rosatum, and gariofilatuÃÑ, sirupus acetosus de citoniis‚ñ™ de prunis, and de m ‚Ä¢ nta de agresta, diafinicon, troch: ramich, & if he vomite choler and flegme, take ye
confectyon de citoniis & a syrupe de calamento, but if it be choler alone, vse these rob de ribes, de agresta, de berberis, de sumach, de moris de sceni, de granis.

These do expel and dissolue al ventosities out of the stomake, Aromaticum gariofilatum, diaciminum oleum nardinum aromaticum nardinum, dianisum trifera saracenia muscata alkanzi trifera hieralogodion ruffi electuarium m ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ, sufuf aromaticum emplastrum de alliis, oleum amigdalarum amararuÃÑ, nucum de kerua & de enula.
Let him that is in a consumption vse these confectio testieulorum vulpis, lochsanum trochisci de camphora oleum amigdalarum dulcium.
These oyles make fat the bodye oleum amigdalarum dulciuÃÑ, sisami de nuce indica, & oleum de granis papaneris.

These confections quenche thyrst and kepe the stomake moist, electuarium de persicis, confectio de acetosis, alxicostum trifera persica, persica condita, Succharum violarum iulep rosarum, syrupus de per ‚Ä¢ icis, de acetositate citri, Acetosus de pomis, de citoniis, de prunis, de cannis, de portulaca, Rob de ribes, de sumach de berberis, de Agresta, de moris, de steni, de granatis, trochisci de camphora, de spodio de berberis, de sandalis & vnguentum rosarum

div.head: ‚òûFor al dyseases in or about the hert. Capi. viii.
div.p: ELectuarium de gemmis, and confection xiloaloes, be good for al diseasys about the hert.

These heale the treÃÑbling and beatyng of the hert confectio de acetosa xiloaloes and de musco syrupus de pomis de prunis conditum de citro de buglosso. rob de agresta coÃÑfectio
xiloaloes.

These confections comfort the hert electuarium de citro, de pomis. Aromaticum rosatum, muscatum, Gariofilat, Dyambra, Pira condita Poma persica, Citra, zuccharum Rosatum syrupus de pomis, rob de ribes de Citoniis de piris, trochisci Gallie muscate, Ramich, sebelline g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ie elephangine, DyarodoÃÑ, sufuf xiloaloes.
Let hym that hath the hert brennynge, vse these, Alxirocostum, syrupus acetosus de succo fructuum Sirupus de Succo Acetose, Rob de Ribes, de Berberis, de Sumach de Moris, de sceni de G ‚Ä¢ anatis.
The confection of xiloaloes doth make a man, merye, so dothe Dyambra and confectio de Musco.
Dyalulphur is good for poysoÃÑ and trifera persica against the pestilence.

div.head: ¬∂For al diseases in the lyuer. Ca. ix.
div.p: THese confectioÃÑs heale al dyseasys of the lyuer yt com of grosse fleygme or ventositie, electuarium de Aromatibus & de gemmis, coÃÑfectio xiloaloes, diacucurma magna confectio de galaÃÑga troch: dianisis emplastrum de gallia, and de sermento, sirupus de thimo, secaniabin de calam: & mellicratum conditum, Also hyerapicra & alharif purge the same.

For the stiche & paynes in the liuer vse confectio diarodon, Athanasia magna sirupus de absinthio, de eupatorio pillule de reubarb. pill: alkakengi, ysopi cerotum & oyle of euphorbium if it come of a cold cause. For the weaknesse & debilitie of the lyuer take Diarodon, Aromaticum muscatum d ‚Ä¢ alacca, confectio alkaÃÑ zi, sirupus de absinthio, citra coÃÑdita trochisti xiloaloes and if it come of great heate emplastrum de gallia &
diafenicon be very goood.

These comfort and make stronge the liuer, Aromaticum nardinum, elect: de granis mirti, confectio de cytonus, sirupus de fumoterrae, conditum de citro & de cytoniis troc: gallie elephangine and ramich pillule aggregate minores oleum costinuÃÑ.

For al inflamations & heate in the lyuer take conf ‚Ä¢ ctio de pomis, de tereniabin, and d ‚Ä¢ portulaca trochisci de caÃÑphora, de spodio cum semine acetose de berberis de sandalis, vnguentum rosarum cerotum saÃÑda. eplastrum de fermento de melliloto andromachi & diaquilon.

The hidro ‚Ä¢ sie of the lyuer is healed wyth tiriaca diatess ‚Ä¢ ron & the oppilatyons therof wyth the confectioÃÑ of fumitory, dycodion Athanasia sirupus de eupatorio de fumoterre secaniabin de kersinii & deradicibus trochisci de Reubarbaro, de Rosis de lacca, de absinthio, and Pillule de
Rauidseni.
Pillule stomatice and aggregate cleÃÑse the lyuer, and coÃÑfectio alrengi, pillule de turbith, and sebellie purge the same.
Cerotum ysopi, troc: de reubarbe and de eupatorio heale an apostem in the lyuer.
Syrupus de agresta, de pomis & de tereniabin, be wounderfull good to quench thurst.

div.head: ¬∂ For all dyseasys in the longes. Cap. x.
div.p: THese clense the longes of al grosse humors. loch de squilla, emplastrum filii zacharie, oleum philosophorum, confectio de musco and sirupus de thimo, also a syrup de granis mirti, doth confort the loÃÑ ges, & it is clensyd wt a syrupe de liqueritia, and oleum cartami.
Oyle of Uyoletes and of swete almondes, do take away the asperitie of the longes.

A iulep of Roses is good for the
‚Ä¢ nflatyon of the longes.

div.head: ¬∂For al diseasys in the splene. Capi. xi.
div.p: UNguentum arthanite, oleum de been and philosophorum, do dyssolue al apostemes and hardnesse of the splene.

For all paynes and oppylatyons of the splenne, take Dyacucurma, Magna Athanasia, Syrupus diacodion, secaniabin de Radicibus, and de Kesin, acetum squilliticum, Sirupus acetosus de Radicibus, de calamento, trochisci de eupatorio de lacca pillule rauedseui, Sebelie and inde, confectio alkekengi, oleuÃÑ, Nardinum, and de euphorbio.

These doo dyssolue and mollyfye the hardnesse of the Splenne, Dyasulphur, secaniabin de Calamento trochisci de Capparis, Cerotum Isopi, Diaquilon, emplastruÃÑ
Andromach and de melliloto oleum philosophorum.

div.head: ¬∂ For al dyseases and paynes in the back ‚Ä¢ and sydes. Capi. xii.
div.p: OLeum de pipere, vulpinum & philosophorum, be good for all paynes in the backe & yf the paynes come of hete take vnguen ‚Ä¢ um de papauere.
These pilles purge the matter whiche causeth paynes in the backe, pillule aggregate maiores de serapino and de oppoponace.
For paynes in the sydes, take philonium loch de squilla loch de alfescera syrupus de ysopo, oleuÃÑ tute & electuarium alesiof purgith ye matter.
Emplastrum Andromachi & aristarchi swage the swelling in ye side.

For the pleurisie take loche de papauere, iulep viol. iniuba ‚Ä¢ um syrupus cucurbite de prums, de granatis, de cannis, de iniubis, de violis &
oleum violaceum.

div.head: ¬∂For all dyseasys in the bealy gutte ‚Ä¢ and entraylles. Cap. xiii.
div.p: EMplastruÃÑ de aliis dyssolueth an apostem of the entraylles.
For the colike take diaciminuÃÑ diafenicon, PhiloniuÃÑ, musa aenea, oleum de cartamo, de lilio and de piperibus.
These purge the humour causiÃÑg the colike, hiera hermetis, electuariuÃÑ induÃÑ, & alesc ‚Ä¢ f, confectio de dactilis, Dyacitoniten, aqua mellis, pillule aggregate and fetide maiores.

For the hidropsye, vse Diacucurma magna, diamorosion diallacca diacoston, diasulphur, Sirupae de cupatorio, trochisci xiloaloes de rosys and de reubarb. emplasters, de alliis and Andronachi, oleum almereseron, and these purge the matter, confectio de eupatorio and de alkakengi, pillule sebelaro, de reubarb, & almeresion, and vnguentuÃÑ arthanita
magum.
Oleum de kerua and de asse be very good for the paynes in the small guttes.
AromaticuÃÑ rosatum drieth vp the humydite of the entrailles.

These conforte and make stronge ye guttes, aromaticum nardinuÃÑ succoruÃÑ rosatuÃÑ, dyacostum, syrypus de granis mirti, mellicratuÃÑ de citoniis. For ye lubricitie of ye bowelles when the meate cometh furth vndigestyd vse these, electuariuÃÑ de granis myrt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , dyalacca, trocisci ramich.

CoÃÑfectio de seminibus, dyacoston, oleuÃÑ lauri heale ye paynes in ye belye which com of wind therin coÃÑteyned, & hiera hermetis wyth electuarium. alescof purge and cleÃÑse ye same, these also be good against al paynes in ye entrayles, oximel squilliticum, diafinicoÃÑ, emplastrum arabicum, oleuÃÑ de ouis, & if it come of slymy flegme take diatrion pipercon, dycyminum
coÃÑfectio anacardina, and an emplaster de granis lauri.
Syrupus calameÃÑti, oleuÃÑ rute, emplastrum aristarchi, do hete ye entrailes yt be cold, and dyaciminum, dianisum, decoctio alhast, dissolue ye veÃÑ tosites in the bely conteyned.
Emplastrum de fermento healeth the inflammations of the guttes, & secaniabin de calamento, or emplastrum de melliloto mollitie the hardnesse therof.

For the fluxe vse the confection de citoniis, citonia, syrupus de albelach and de meÃÑta, emplast ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ de gallia, and if it come of choler take el ‚Ä¢ ctuarium de fructibus, sirupus acetosus de succis fructuum, Trochisci de spodio, emplastrum diafinicon and yf the Fluxe be bloudy athanasia magna‚ñ™ is good, but if the cause be flegme take confectio de storace, rob de fructubus, trochisci de Berberis.
Succharum violaceuÃÑ maketh the bely loose.

div.head: ¬∂For all paynes in the raynes and bladder. Capi. xiiii.
div.p: THese confections heate the reynes, electuarium de aromatibus, trifera galeni, secacul coÃÑdituÃÑ, confectio de zingibere, oleuÃÑ de lilio & de ruta, aromaticum rosatum.

For the paynes in the reynes, and bladder take diacucurma, dyamorusion, philoniuÃÑ eÃÑplm de granis lauri oleum, lauri, de keyri, de ruta de asse de piperibus, oleum vulpinum, philosophorum and nardinum.
These breake the stone in the reynes and bladder, dialacca, oleum de nucleis cerasorum, de granis citrangulorum, de scorpionibus, & de piperibus.
Hyerapicra, hyera hermetis, electuarium indy, purge the raynes.

Syrupus acetosus, de radicibus, openeth the opilations of the reines
and trochisci alkakeÃÑgi heale the vlcers therof.
For the hardnesse of the bladder vse cerotuÃÑ ysopi, and for ye breÃÑninge heate therof Oleum amigdalarum dulcium.

These prouoke vrine, diacalameÃÑ tum, diacucurma, diamorusion, diasulphur, secaniabin de radicibus, & de cheisyu, trochisci de lacca, pillule aggregate, oleum philosophoruÃÑ, philonium, masa aen ‚Ä¢ i, oleum aske.
Oleum quartuor seminum frigidorum maiorum is veri good for all brennyng and heate in the yarde
Syrupus de piris and de citoniis be good for hym yt loseth his nature

div.head: ¬∂For al diseases in the matrix and pryuy membres. Ca. ix.
div.p: GErotum ysopi mollifieth the hardnesse of matrixe.

For the paynes in the matrix comenly called the moder, take diambra oleum nardinum, philonium, musa
aenea, emplastrum de granis, lacca, de ruta de croco, and philosophoruÃÑ, and if the paynes come of colde, vse oleum de enula, and hyerapicra, hiera hermetis, pillule de serapino, experte.
These heate a cold matrix electuarium de gemmis, oleuÃÑ rute lilii an de piperibus.
Aromaticum muscatum and oleuÃÑ de lapide gagatis, be very good for the moder.
DiacalamentuÃÑ and pillule de serapino expert prouoke ye floures, and trifera minor stoppe the same.

div.head: ¬∂For the hemorrhoydes and all dyseasys of the foundameÃÑt. Cap. xvi.
div.p: OYle of lynseed is good for all paynes in the fundament. Trifera saracenica, trifera muscata trifera galeni confectio alkakengi heale ye hemorrhoydes, & these asswage the paines therof, oleum de grisomilis and de nucleis persicorum.

These stop the flux of ye hemorrhoides,
pillule de bdellio maiores & minores, and of the contrary parte pillule aggregate, lose the same.
If they swel anoynt them with oleum de grisomilis.

div.head: ¬∂For the goute, ye sciatica, and all other vlcers & ache in the outward meÃÑbres. Ca. xvii
div.p:
OLeum viola
rum , and cerotuÃÑ sandalium, ar good for al hote apostemes & these ripe & dissolue ye same, cerotuÃÑ andromachi, emplastrum de fermeÃÑ to, and dyaquilon.

OleuÃÑ auellanaruÃÑ, vulpinum, de lapide gagatis, & philosophoruÃÑ heale a cold goute, & if it be hote vse oleuÃÑ de ranis‚ñ™ &, for an old gout‚ñ™ cerotum alexandri, oleuÃÑ de nucleis cerasoruÃÑ & de granis citrangulorum be very good. hieralogodioÃÑ, & hamech purg a caÃÑcer or crabbe, & these ointmentes heale ye same, diafinicon alphesericoÃÑ emplastrum arabuÃÑ. oleuÃÑ iun ‚Ä¢ peri & de fraxino, & these ripe & breke it, sirupus de epithimio, pillule inde.
These dissolue al hard knobbes & swellinges, dialacca, oleum amigdalarum dulcium, and sisaminum, cerotum ysopi emplastrum diaquilon and de alliis.

Oleum lilii, masticum and sinapis, ease al paynes whiche come of cold, but if they be hote take oleuÃÑ rosaruÃÑ & de papauere, & these asswage al aches, oleum rosatuÃÑ, camomilli, & de melliloto wt cerotuÃÑ andromachi.

Unguentum egiptiacum clenseth an old fistula very well, but yeralogodion ruffi purgeth the matter, & these oyntmentes heale the fistula, vnguentum diafeÃÑicon. de lino and alphesericoÃÑ, oleum de onis, syrupus de epithimo and emplastrum arabuÃÑ

Pillule aggregate and de oppoponaco purge the mater that causethe paynes in the knees, and emplast ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ andromachi taketh away the ache. These purge al goutes of cold causes, hyerapigra, hierahermetis, electu
‚Ä¢ ium
iuduÃÑ, confeetioÃÑ alkakengi, pillule alhandhal, de hermodactilis & de oppoponaco, but if it come of a hote cause, take electuariuÃÑ de succo rosarum, and these purge all kynde of goutes, electuarium alescof, pillule stomatiche, aggregate, fetide, of serapino and coloquintide.
Anoynt cold ioyntes wyth cerotum alexandri, and oleum de stincho conforteth lose ioyntes.

For al paynes in the ioyntes, take aqua mellis, oleuÃÑ masticum, de storace, de euphorbio, de been, de lauro de keire de cucumere asimino, de granis citrangulorum & de piperibus, also vse cerotum isopi, acetum squilliticum, emplastrum andromachi & filii zacharie.
Emplastrum diaquilon ripeth all swellynges.
Trifera sarasenica is good for werinesse.

Unguentum alphesericon, oleum
de iunipero and de fraximo healeth the paynes in the legges.
Confectio de asse & diasulphur be good for bytynges of venemouse beastes.
Emplastrum de fermento draweth al fixed things out of ye body. For ye sciatica take emplastrum andromachi, eÃÑplm sinapis, oleum de piperibus and philosophor.
Anoynt thy body with oyle of dyl & thou shalt sweate, and oyle of quinces doth stoppe the swette.
Pillule aggregate maiores and serapine purge the sciatica.
Hyeralogodion ruffi & pillule aggregate minores purge foul vlcers
UngueÃÑtum nobile, nichodemi ceraseos, & ceruse, oleum almezereoÃÑ de iunipero & de fraxino heale old vlcers
Oleum de beeÃÑ taketh a way ye skarre of an vlcer.
UngueÃÑtuÃÑ sericinum & vnguentuÃÑ ceruse heale al brinning wt fyre.

div.head:
‚Ä¢ For woundes and al dyseases in the syno
‚Ä¢ es Capi. xviii.
div.p:
HYera hermetis purgeth well all ‚Ä¢ ymy ma ‚Ä¢ ier coÃÑteyned in ye sinowes ‚Ä¢ o do pillule alhaÃÑdal & de opopona
‚Ä¢ o, for cold diseases in ye sinowe, vse ‚Ä¢ irupus sticados, aquamellis, vngueÃÑtum de bdellio, oleum, nardinuÃÑ, de croco, de piperibus, de euphorbio de storace, de scorace, de beeÃÑ, & oleum de enula, cerotuÃÑ andromachi, oleum costinum & de sanbuco, oleuÃÑ nucuÃÑ, & if they haue a coÃÑtractioÃÑ cerotuÃÑ AlexaÃÑdri, & for ach in ye sinowes, take ysopi cerotuÃÑ, oleuÃÑ amigdalarum amararum, auellanaruÃÑ, nucuÃÑ, lauri, taÃÑoniil, saÃÑbuci, keyri, melliloti, mast ‚Ä¢
cis, and de euphorbio.
If the sinowes be hard or swolleÃÑ, take oyle of bytter almoÃÑdes, of lynsed of safron, of nuttes, and of laurel, & oyle of quynces is good for loose synowes.
CoÃÑfectio alphescera & balanscioch good for the synowes.
UnguentuÃÑ diaphenicoÃÑ & vngueÃÑ tum arabum be very good for broken bones.
Emplastrum synapis is good for paine in ye bones if it come of a cold cause, and emplastrum de fermento draweth out broken bones.

Syrupus de epithimo vnguentuÃÑ de lino, diafinicoÃÑ, emplastrum Arabicum, vnguentum daceraseos, doo wonderful clense and heale wouÃÑdes and if the wound putrifie, take vnguentuÃÑ cericinium, and egiptiacum magnum, and if the synow be hurte take vnguentum basilicoÃÑ magnuÃÑ.
OleuÃÑ philosophorum is good for an olde sore, and oleuÃÑ de grisomilis asswagith the swelling in a wound and emplastrum de fermento drieth vp a hurt ye mattreth wonderfully.

Emplastrum andromachi aliud, doth breÃÑne and consume the skynne
‚Ä¢ nd fleshe as it were a cautery.

For the crampe, take sirupus stic ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ os, pillule de serapino, vnguentuÃÑ
‚Ä¢ ebdellio, oleum de been, de croco, ‚Ä¢ e piperibus, and de lapide gagatis

div.head: ¬∂ For al agewes. Cap. xix.
div.p: FOr al hote Agewes, vse confectio de acetosis, de prunis, sirupus cucurbite, & Acetosus ‚Ä¢ e pomis, iuleb violaceum, cerotum violaceum, trochisci de rosis, and de spodio, reubarbarum, trochisci de eupatorio.

For the quartane, take confectio de assa, de dactilis, diasulphur, sirupus de eupatorio, secaÃÑiabin de radicibus & de calamento, infusio de hyera, dyarhodon, trocisci de rosis, de eupatorio, de absinthio with pillule inde be good for a quartayne.
These purge sharpe agues, trifera persica, alxilcostes, coÃÑfectio de dactilis, syrupus acetosus de succis herbarum, and decoctio cupatorii.
For hote feuers, vse iuleb violaruÃÑ sirupus de prunis, de granatis, de acetositate citri, de portulaca, trotisci de caÃÑphora de berberis & de saÃÑdalis, & ye same be good for pestileÃÑt agues.
Sirupus de bisantiis, is good for olde feuers of longe continuance, & so is confectio de psillio, & for cholerike agues take syrupus de succo acetose and agresta.
Sirupus acetosus de tereniabin, is good for hote feuers yt be veri perillouse, & for agues in ye which diuers humores be putrified take sirupus diacodioÃÑ, troc ‚Ä¢ sci de rosis & eupatori ‚Ä¢
Decoctio de sticados & trocisci diarodon heale agues that com of corrupt flegme.
These purge al kiÃÑd of agues, pillule aggregate, de rubarbaro de alkakengi, & in the cold or shakinge it is good to anoynte the pacient wt oyle of dyl or de enula.

div.head: ‚òûFor al corruptyon and dyseases in the foure humors bloud, choler, flegme, and melancholye. Capi. xx.
div.p: HYeralogodion ruffi, hamech, decoctio epithimi do purge melaÃÑcholy These purge choler wonderful wel coÃÑfectio de psillio coÃÑfectio de manna, electuariuÃÑ rosa ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ, diacitonites, pillule de turbith, de coloquintida, sirupus acetosus laxarinus, aqua fructuum, aqua casei, insu ‚Ä¢ io de succis herbarm, coÃÑfectio fumiterre, and de croco, with myrabolanes.

To purge choler adust, take syrupus minor fumoter, syrupus de epithimo, acetuÃÑ squilliticum and decoctio capilli veneris pillule de lapide lazuli and de armuico, pillule stomatiche purge both choler and melancholy

These aswage & delay ye hete of choler, succharum violac ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ, sirupus acetosus laxatiuus, & syrupus acetosus de succo fructuuÃÑ. Grosse & thike choler is made thine & easy to degest wt, sirupus acetosus de radicibus, secaÃÑiabiÃÑ de radicibÍù∞, trocisci de ramich
These be good to purge flegme, hieralogodion ruffi, decoctio alharif, & of myrabolanes, pillule de euphorbio, de turbith, stomatch, de satcocolla de serapino and de coloquintida.
If thou wyll breake grosse & slymy flegme take syrupus maior de fumoterre.

Diacala: galeni, purgeth al slymy matter so doth acetum squilliticum pillule aggregate maiores, and fetide minores, infusio hyere, and if the humores descend to ye sinowes, take pillule de euphorbio and laye to the place euplastrum de alliis.
ConfectioÃÑ de dactilis purgeth rawe humores wounderfull well.

The bloude is muÃÑdyfyed & made cleare from all corruptyon by these confections, coÃÑfectio anacardina, decoctio capilli venetis, aqua fructuuÃÑ decoctio fumiterre, and pillule ad febres cholericas purge the bloud.

Aqua fructuum, Alxicostum trochisci
de camphora, delay the heate of the bloud.

Athanasia magna and trochisci de terra sigillata be good for them that spittte bloud, but for bleding at the nose take trochisci de ramiche de terra sigillata and de karabe, and they be also good for a bloudy flux, oleuÃÑ philosophorum dissolueth bloud gathered to one place.
Rob de prunis, de fructibus, trochisci sandalorum, vnguentum rosarum, violarum and oleum mandragore be good for al inflamatioÃÑs and brennynges.
Hamech purgeth al dyseasys whiche come of choler or salte flegme.

These open oppilations thrughe all the body, diacyminum, coÃÑfectio de seminibus, syrupus acetosus, de succis herbarum‚ñ™ de fumoterre, secaniabin de radicibus, trochisti de aniso, pillule aggregate minores, ol ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ amigdalarum amararum, de been,
costinuÃÑ, persicorum & de piperibus.
Electuarium alescof purgeth the superfluities of al the body.
These purge melancholike, pillule inde, lucis maiores, de lapide lazuli and zebelie.

‚úö A Table conteyning ye weightes which phisicyons do comenly vse, & the interpretacyon of the names of the compound medicynes herin conteyned wyth the quaÃÑtitie & tyme yt they ought to be receyued in.

THe least & fyrst of al weightes (comoÃÑly vsed amoÃÑg phisicyons) is a barly corne, and .xx. cornes make a scruple, thre scrupules make a drachme, eyght drachmes make an vnce, xii. vnces make apouÃÑ de. A quarter of pouÃÑd is thre vnces,
All compounde medycynes be eyther receyuid wythin the body, or layd to the same without‚ñ™ & they whych be receyued into ye body be these.

ELectuarium & confectio differ in thys alone, that electuariuÃÑ is moyst and made wyth sugger and hony, & confectio drye made alonly wyth suger, and because they be for dyuerse diseases theris nooe certayne tyme or measure, for the receyuing of them.

Mixtura is wheÃÑ diuerse electuaries or coÃÑfections be mingled together, & is receyued .ii. houres be fore meate. Tragea is wheÃÑ dyuerse pouders be meÃÑgled together wt suger and they be receiued a . í. at onest wt soppes of stronge wyne.
Conserua & condituÃÑ be wheÃÑ diuerse spyces be mixt with sume sirup and be comeÃÑly receiuid early and late after the bygnesse of a walnut.
Loth is a medycyne which may be lyked wyth the tonge, & may be receiued at al tymes in the quantitie of a hasel nutte.
Iuleb is a cleare potyon made of dyuerse waters and suger.
Rob is a ioyce made hard & thick wyth the heat of the soÃÑne or of ye fire and is comonly mingled with electuarys, and conserues.
Syrupe is a moyst medicyne whiche maye be receyuyd earlye or late
Decoctum is a medicine made of rotes leaues, sead and floures wher vnto is added sugger or hony.
Infusio is when diuerse medycins be beaten to pouder or hole layde to stepe a certayne space in sum liquor

Trochiscus is a rounde confectioÃÑ and plaine, made after the maner of a whele, the which before it be receiuyd moost be beaten to pouder, and dronke with wyne or other licoure the weyght of one í. comonly.
Pilles be knoweÃÑ to al men & ought to be receyued two or thre houres at after souper the quantitie of . í i.
Sief is a confectyon made after the fashioÃÑ of a suger lofe & most be dyssoluyd in licour before it be receiuid
Collirium is a moyst confection made of sief dissolued.
Sufuf is a fyne pouder made of dyuerse spices.
Secaniabin is a sharpe syrupe wherin is put suger or hony.
MasticatoriuÃÑ is a confection whiche is held in the mouth & chewed to purge the head of flegme.
SuffimeÃÑtum or suffumigatio is when diuerse pouders be cast vpon the cooles, and the pacyent doth receyue the smoke therof.
Gargarisme is a confectyon of diuerse maters and sume decoctyon wherin sume rob is dissolued, which is gargarised in the mouth and not swalowed downe.
Here folow the compound medycynes whyche be applyed to the outwarde partes of the body.
UNgueÃÑtuÃÑ an ointmeÃÑt, is made of oyles, spices & waxe, & ought hote to be applyed to the place beiÃÑg sumwhat before rubbed wt a lynen clothe.
LinimentuÃÑ is in all poyntes lyke to vngueÃÑtuÃÑ sauing that ther goeth no waxe to the composityon therof.
Emplastrum is made of herbes & spices, not being beatinge to pouder but a litel bruysed mixt wyth sume liquore or decoctyon, & beinge hote is put vpon a lineÃÑ cloth and so layd so layd to the sore.
Plus dyffereth not from an emplaster sauing that mele or branne god to the composityon therof.
Cataplasma is made of grene herbes or drye sod in water tyll they be soft & then applyed to the sore.

CerotuÃÑ is made of wax or rosyn wt oyles & spyces, and is layde vpon a
cloth cut after the fourme of the meÃÑ bre it shuld be applyed vnto.
Dropax is an oyntment only vsyd to take away heare.
Sinapismus is an emplaster made of mustard to vlcerate the skynne & make the same red.
Epithema is made of diuerse pouders mixt wt suÃÑe ioice or distilled water, and comonly layd vpon skarlet is applyed to the seke membre.
Embrocha is when the membre is washed gentilly wyth a spoÃÑge dypt in the decoction of diuerse herbes, rotes and floures.
FomentuÃÑ is a bath made of the decoctyon of dyuerse herbes to washe the sore place wyth al.
Euaporatio is when the diseased membre is holden in ye hote vapour of some decoctyon.

Saceuly be bagges made of linen cloth wherin be coÃÑteyned herbes rotes and leaues whyche beynge hote muste be fyrste dypte in Wyne or
vineger, and then layd to the membre that is greuyd.
Encathisma or insessio is a decoctyon of certayne thynges wherin ye pacyent most sit for certayne space.
