div.head: The epystle of Diocles vnto king Antigonus, which teacheth a man to preserue hym selfe in health.
div.p:
IN so muche that youre grace beyng nowe sumwhat runne in yeares (most noble Prince Antigonus) is endowed with knowl ‚Ä¢ dge aboue other kinges, and that in all partes of Phil ‚Ä¢ sophy and the artes called Mathematicall wherin your grace hathe wounderfully profited: I thought that parte of Philosophy whyche teacheth a man to preserue hymselfe in health not worthy to be dyspysed and left vntouched of your regal maiestye, wherfore I thought it necessari to declare v ‚Ä¢ to your maiesty in thys Epistle, the causes of dyuerse diseases wyth the sygnes and tokeÃÑs which goo before the same, and last of all the remedyes wherwyth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e same may be healed and cured, for like as the „Äà‚óä„Äâ no raginge & hideouse tempest wythout sum ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ anifest and open sygnes which declare the same to folowe, wherby men which haue knowledge and be lerned in ye Arcane and preuy workes of nature do so prouyde for themselues that they be sure from all perylles and i ‚Ä¢ operdyes that may ensue, so is ther no kynd of disease or sicknesse that maye infecte any membre of mannes bodye but that hath before suche euydent sygnes and tokens that it may be easlye knowen to folow. Therfore your grace puttyng your trust and confidence
in those our preceptes may easly attaine to the perfect and absolute knowledge of all thynges.
First of all I haue deuyded the body of man vnto foure partes, that is to say the head, the brest, the bely, and the bladder.

Th ‚Ä¢ se sygnes and tokens do de ‚Ä¢ lare when any kynd of disease is about to infecte the head, daselyng in the eyes, the headache, heuynesse of y‚Ä¢ browes, a noyse in the eares, prichinge in the temples, the eyes to water in the morninge & the syght to fayle, wt dulnesse or want of smellynge and the liftyng vp of the gummes.

When thou doest perceyue any such tokens, it is the best remedy to purge & clense the head (and that wyth no purgatyue medycyne) but wyth, v. vnces of wyne made of wytheryd grapes, or of new wyne sodde till half ‚Ä¢ e wasted a way, therwith thou shalt washe t ‚Ä¢ y mouth fastynge, and gargarise it therin till the head be purged of flegme therin conteyned, and this is the easyest remedy for al dyseasys in the head. Also it were very good and helthful, if the pacyent fastynge wold eate a quaÃÑtitie of mustard whych haue bene macerate or steped in ‚Ä¢ at ‚Ä¢ r and hony myngled together, & gagarysynge the same wold drawe downe the humore conteyned in the head, but fyrst of all yo ‚Ä¢ moost take hede the heade be coueryd tyill it h ‚Ä¢ ar, wherby the slymy flegme may b ‚Ä¢ made more apt & mere to flowe downe to the mouth.

Now of the contrary part, whose despiseth these sygnes and tokens shalbe troubled wyth these deseases, or one of them, the ophtalmy, ye perle in the ey ‚Ä¢ s, brekyng out about the cares poukes or weles in the necke, the c ‚Ä¢ nsumptyoÃÑ in the brayne, heuinesse in the head, the squinaÃÑ
eye, wormes whiche eate the heare, the paynes in the flape that coueryth the wynde pype, the fallynge of the heare, s ‚Ä¢ abbes or vlcers in the head, and the totheache.

You maye perceyue by these tokens yf anye man is lyke to be diseasyd about the breast or no, fyrst a swette throughe al the body & breast the tunge to waxe roughe or thyck ‚Ä¢ , the spittel to be salt or bytter in tast or cholericke, sodein paynes in the sydes or shulders wythout manyfest occasyon, of tyaning much watchynge, suffocatyones, thurst after sleape, greate sadnesse, coldnesse in the breast, and a shakyng in the armes and handes, and the dyseases therof ensuing you maye auoyde wyth perbraking after a meane supper, wythout receyuinge any medycyne. Also it is very good to vomyt fastynge,

Therfore let hym that wold vomit, eate Radyshe, Towneressys, Roket, Mustarde‚ñ™ or purslane, and afterwarde drynke warme wat ‚Ä¢ r & he shall vomyt furthwith, but he that serrythe lyt ‚Ä¢ ll by these presagyes and sygnes ought to feare these diseasys, the pleurisy, paynes in the longes, melancholical madnesse, sharpe agues, the phrenesy, the lythargye, and a burnynge ague wyth yeskynge.

When ye bely shall be dyseasyd, sume of these sygnes do comenly appeare before, the throwes and paynes in the bely, meates and drinkes to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me bytter, heuinesse in the knees, cold stifnesse in the loynes, wearynesse of al the bodye wythout any occasyon, lacke of senses in the legges, and easye feuers, Now when ‚Ä¢ riye of these tokens do appeare it is best to make ye belly ‚Ä¢ soft and lose wyth some kynde of dyete
and wt no purgiÃÑg medicyne, for it is leasse ieopardye to vse such thynges that a man maye skant erre in, as betes sodde wt water & hony, sodde garlike, malowes, dockes, or mercurye and swete metes made wyth hony, for all these thynges do mollifye the bely, but if any of the foresayde sygnes be manifest or endure longe adde to the sayde decoctyons the ioyce of b ‚Ä¢ stard Saffron, for therby it shalbe swetter and more holsome. Also Col ‚Ä¢ wortes sod in a great quantitie of water, or foure vnces of ye ioyce therof receyuid wyth hony and salte, is verye good, and of no lesse effect is the water of the decoctyon of Cichepcasen or bitterfitch droÃÑke fastynge, But they which thinke these sygnes to be of none effecte, are oftentymes dyseased wt these syknesses, the flux in the belly, paynes in ye bowelles, the lyenceri, iliaca pa ‚Ä¢ sio which is a disease in the smale guttes, the ‚Ä¢ ciatica, the feuer tertyan, the goute in ye feete, ye apoplexye the hemorrhoydes, and the ioynte syknesse.

Al dyseases of the bladder, ‚Ä¢ e knoweÃÑ by these tokens, to be very ful after lytle meate, great in flatyons, much b ‚Ä¢ lc ‚Ä¢ ynge, the pale colour of all the body, heuye or sad sleape, vryne wane of coloure, and great paynes in the making ther of, wyth swellyng about the pryuye membres, after whiche tokens it is good to vse odoriferouse thynges which moue vrine, as the rotes of Fenel or persely whyche haue ben steped a whyle in good & doriferouse white wyne, of yt whych let the pacyent take euery mornyng fastyng thre vnces wt the water af yelowe carettes or lonage or enula campana, for they be of lyke operation, & of no lesse effica ‚Ä¢ y is ye water wherin Ciches haue bene steped in, if it be dronke wyth wyne. But whoso doth lyghtli passouer these tokeÃÑs shall loke for sume of these
dyseases the hydropsye, the bygnesse of the splene, paynes in the lyu ‚Ä¢ r, the stone, paynes in the raynes, the strangurye, and th ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ stentioÃÑ of the be ‚Ä¢ y. And her it is to be noted that in al these sygnes before rehersed we ought to mynister gentle and easy medecines to children, and to such as be elder, medycynes that be of more stronge operatyon and greater efficacye.

Now I entende brefly to declare vnto your maiestye the two turnynges of the sone callid in latyn solstitia (at which tymes suche thinges do comenli chance) and what meates your ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ur grace shall vse or absteyne from in eyther of them, takynge my begynning at the wynter turnynge.

div.head: ¬∂ The wynter turne.
div.p:
SoluÃÑitiuÃÑ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ emale wich I call yt wiÃÑter turne is about ye xi. day of December when the soÃÑe entreth the Goate.IN the winter turne do rewmes and humiditie encrease in meÃÑnes bodyes tyl ye spriÃÑg equinoctiall, therfore it is good to eate who ‚Ä¢ e meates and to drynke swete wynes and especially wyth wild marg ‚Ä¢ ram, and also to vse ye company of women.
‚òûTher be from the wynter turnynge to the spryng equinoctiall nynty dayes.

div.head: ¬∂ The springtyme equinoctial.
div.p: ¬∂From the spryng equinoctiall vnto the rysynge of the seueÃÑ sterres callyd vergiliac, doth flegme and swette corruptyon of the bloud engendre in mans body,The spring equinoctial is ye .x. daye of Marche wheÃÑ the son entreth the Rame. and for that cause it is good to vse moyst and tarte meates, to excercise ye body, & not to absteyne from women, froÃÑ the springe equinoctial to the rysynge of pleyad ‚Ä¢ s be .xivi. dayes.

div.head: ‚ùßThe rysynge of the seuen starres.
div.p: ‚òûCholer and vytter matter berythe rule in man from this tyme vnto the somer turnynge,The seuen sters called vergilia ‚Ä¢ or p ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ adÍù≠ rise wt the sene about ye .ix day of may therfore vse meates that be swete, laxatiue, & beware of actes venereal, froÃÑ the resig ‚Ä¢ e of p ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ ades vnto the somer turne be xlv dayes.

div.head: ‚òûThe somer turnynge.
div.p: ‚òúAt thys tyme is melancholye augmentyd tell the heruest equinoctiall, therfore dryncke cold water and smell odoriferouse thynges,The somer turne is about .x. of Iuly, when the sone entreth the Crabbe. & as for ‚Ä¢ enus you most eyther vse it moderatly or exchew it vtterly, we haue to the heruest equinoctial nynty and thre dayes.

div.head: ¬∂The heruest equinoctiall.
div.p: ¬∂Flegme & thine flurrons abounde froÃÑ thys tyme to the settyng of ye seuyn sterres,The heruest equinoctiall is about ye. 14 of SepteÃÑ bre wheÃÑ the son entreth the balaÃÑce. therfore it is good to purge ye humoures or to stoppe ye fluxyons, and to eate al tarte and moyst meates, to perbrake nothynge at all, to excercyse ye body, and to flee women, from whych tyme to the settyng of the seuin sterres be .xxxvi. days.

div.head: ‚òûThe settyng of the seuen Sterres.
div.p: ‚òûFrom thys tyme to the wynter turnynge doth flegme bere domynyon in man,The seuyn sterres set wt the sone about ye .x. of noueÃÑbre therfore you most eate fat & bytter thynges, drynke swete wynes, and excercyse the body, from the going downe of the .vii sterres tyll the Wynter turne be fyue and fourty dayes.
